The Venus Project is pleased to introduce
some interviewees from our forthcoming series

9.28.text: I'm Jeff Hoffman. I'm professor of aerospace engineering

13.12.text: in the department of aeronautics and astronautics at MIT.

17.10.text: Prior to coming here, I spent 25 years at NASA as a NASA astronaut

22.18.text: and made five flights in various space shuttles.

26.10.text: I was the first astronaut to log 1,000 hours on the space shuttle,

31.50.text: and I was one of the crew in the rescue mission

34.54.text: for the Hubble Space Telescope back in 1993.

39.40.text: All over the world there are places where we can see the artificial borders

45.11.text: that humans have put up and the different ways that we take care

48.72.text: of the land on either side of the borders.

51.66.text: So, it's like the many other impacts

55.15.text: the Human race has had on our planet.

59.26.text: It's a situation where we've affected our planet

63.08.text: in ways that are visible from a cosmic perspective,

66.30.text: and it should give us pause.

69.00.text: I'm Karen Hudes. I'm known as the World Bank whistle-blower.

72.21.text: I'm working with a team of other whistle-blowers,

74.53.text: both from the World Bank and outside the World Bank,

77.62.text: to tell you what's been hidden from you—deliberately hidden from you.

82.20.text: The Federal Reserve system is a private system—it's not a central bank.

86.71.text: And these bankers are all part of a system

93.90.text: They own 40% of the assets of the 43,000 companies

99.39.text: that are traded on the capital market,

101.18.text: and they pull down 60% of the annual earnings.

105.10.text: They bought up all our media; and that media is hoodwinking the citizens.

110.53.text: At the vanguard of this new wave of automation is the field of robotics.

114.35.text: But instead of serving us, we find them competing for our jobs,

118.02.text: and, according to MIT professors Erik Brynjolfsson and Andrew McAfee,

122.25.text: one of the reasons for the jobless recovery.

124.65.text: I’m Erik Brynjolfsson. I’m a professor at MIT

128.35.text: and the director of the MIT initiative on the digital economy.

132.80.text: Every new technology both destroys jobs and creates jobs.

137.20.text: There are winners and there are losers.

139.10.text: There’s disruption, and that’s certainly true with this wave,

142.02.text: even as it creates record wealth.

144.46.text: We’re now at $77 trillion with record productivity and record GDP.

149.45.text: There are a lot of people who are actually worse off than they were before.

153.92.text: My name is Abby Martin and I am a journalist for mediaroots.org

157.48.text: and a host of Breaking The Set on RT America.

162.64.text: The media’s morphed into just peddling the corporate interests

166.26.text: of the money masters that control the political establishment.

170.35.text: I don’t even consider us to live in a democracy at all;

174.56.text: there’s a corporatocracy that’s running the planet,

177.30.text:
and under this corporatocracy, we have them (corporations)
using the state as a tool of the market.

183.35.text: And so, we’re at a state now

185.15.text: [where] all of their interests [are] bleeding into the media.

190.50.text: My name is Paul Wright and I’m the executive director and the founder

195.32.text: I’m also the editor of 'Prison Legal News',

197.94.text: and I've published and edited three anthologies on mass incarceration,

202.70.text: starting with 'The Celling of America: An Inside look at the U.S. Prison Industry',

206.46.text: followed by 'Prison Nation: The Warehousing of America’s Poor',

210.70.text: and 'Prison Profiteers: Who Makes Money from Mass Incarceration'.

215.44.text: Generally, the laws in this country are written by the wealthy and the powerful

219.21.text: because, by definition, that’s who controls legislatures

222.68.text: and the commanding heights of the power system in this country.

227.21.text:
The government is not a neutral agent;
it serves the class that holds power.

233.70.text: I’m a professor of civil and environmental engineering at Stanford University,

238.20.text: and I build computer models to simulate climates, air pollution, and weather

244.10.text: on global, regional, and local scales.

246.75.text: I also study and develop solutions to the problems of

251.22.text: global warming, air pollution, and air-pollution health problems

255.73.text: with the goal of trying to provide energy stability for years to come.

260.24.text: There’s no technological or economic limitation to solving these problems;

264.73.text: it’s a social and political issue, primarily.

272.20.text: I am the recently retired host of 'The Dylan Ratigan Show' on MSNBC.

277.75.text: It was the highest rated non-primetime show on the network.

280.77.text: Prior to that, I was the host and creator

283.31.text: of a program on CNBC entitled 'Fast Money',

286.73.text: which was the single highest-grossing, highest-rated

289.40.text: show in the history of CNBC.

291.70.text: I have resigned all those positions 18 months ago

295.93.text: in order to follow the leadership

297.99.text: of recently-returned Iraq and Afghanistan war veterans

300.73.text: who have explained to me that the necessary solution to global conflict

305.41.text: is the tactical application of global resource management,

308.87.text: and I have devoted my life to helping them achieve that goal.

314.38.text: I’m a reporter for RT television

316.12.text: and host of 'Boom Bust', a financial and economic show on RT.

got into the game to change the world, but,

327.10.text:
if they’re any good at their job,
they’re no longer changing the world;

That’s a scary reality because you can pay
your way into having laws implemented

340.74.text:

370.00.text: But in general, it’s the best way

373.45.text: of looking and interacting with the world — rationality.

379.04.text: What will Earth look like 50 years from now?

382.07.text: It’s something scientists, sci-fi fans, and a lot of kids daydream about.

386.05.text: But, there’s also a big dreamer right here in Florida

388.06.text: who may just be the oldest living futurist.

391.80.text: Jacque Fresco has a vision, a very serious vision, for the 21st century.

396.96.text:
It’s all in keeping with his life’s work:
The Venus Project.
